## Impacts

- Arkansas will become warmer,and the state will probably experience more severe floods
and drought. 
- Unlike most of the nation, Arkansas has not become warmer during the last 50 to 100 years. 
- Annual rainfall has increased in much of the state, and more rain
arrives in heavy downpours.
- Changing the climate is likely to increase damage from storms, reduce crop yields, harm
livestock, 
- Increase the number of unpleasantly hot days, and increase the risk of heat stroke and other heat-related
illnesses.

[EPA Snapshot](https://19january2017snapshot.epa.gov/sites/production/files/2016-09/documents/climate-change-ks.pdf)

## State Adaptation / Mitigation Plans

- Arkansas has not developed a statewide adaptation plan.

[Source: Georgetown Climate Center] (https://www.georgetownclimate.org/adaptation/state-information/arkansas/overview.html)
